10 Nov 2023 07:00
RNS Number : 0080T
Cambridge Nutritional Sciences PLC
10 November 2023
Cambridge Nutritional Sciences plc
(the 'Company' or 'CNS')
Warrant Expiry
and
Block Admission Cancellation
Cambridge Nutritional Sciences plc (AIM: CNSL), the specialist medical diagnostics company focused on promoting a personalised and functional approach to health and nutrition, announces that all warrants issued alongside its capital raise announced 6 May 2022 have now expired ("
Warrants
").
Further to the above the Company has made application to AIM to cancel the Company's Block Admission, which was originally established to facilitate the issuance of ordinary shares following receipt of any exercise of the Warrants (the "
Cancellation
"). The Cancellation will become effective Monday 13 November, as such no further interim returns will be published in relation to the Company's Block Admission. The Balance of ordinary shares under the Block Admission not issued/allotted at the time of Cancellation is 90,000,000.

Cambridge Nutritional Sciences plc (AIM: CNSL), the specialist medical diagnostics company focused on promoting a personalised and functional approach to health and nutrition,
confirms it will issue its Half Year results for the six months ended 30 September 2023 on Thursday 23 November 2023.
Investor presentation

will provide a live presentation relating to the Half Year Results via the Investor Meet Company platform on Thursday 23 November 2023 at 16:30 BST.

data.author: Atanasoff
data.content: When will you start listening to me instead of just attacking? Revenue down, as expected. The sales team aren’t performing. At this stage that is all that matters. They need a consultant in to  see what is going wrong, if anything. Share is back to record lows. Haven’t read the whole thing yet so may see more horrors !

data.author: CaptainSwag
data.content: Well as i have been saying on numerous times to counter the contentious potential  "pay for play"  awards. Sales are going in one direction - down more worry is that cash burn is worse than i expected

data.author: Atanasoff
data.content: Now read it in the time it took the share price to hit 2.25p This is now a record low (remember my post about the potential for it to hit this?) Cash burn  could be a combination of the sales  reorganisation and the new gut detective R&D (which will have tax benefits). So nothing to panic over  - although it gives them 2 years at the current rate. It is good to see they have reorganised the sales team but reading between the lines it would seem that (as I have highlighted in the past) manufacturing companies aren't always the best at running sales teams. It seems they went for a "hit and hope" global strategy which is fatal. An American buyer is very different to a European buyer. A sales team not performing after 6 months won't perform unless changed. Sales people are different from account managers. Never the twain should meet because they ALWAYS retreat to the comfort zone of existing clients. (This is very expensive advice give to you gratis). Interesting.

data.author: Atanasoff
data.content: Today's economic figures aren't good for CNSL. The UK market is key for CNSL despite it being near saturation. Discretionary spending is clearly taking a hit. The crystal gazing market has some robustness against this (a fool and its money) but my suspicion is that they will be like many other SME and seeing a fall in sales in the UK market. So how about its international ambitions? The US dollar has and continues to weaken against sterling. Trading is still tough for importers with tariffs and the general political mood music. I think sales are static at best. India was also another target (assuming that is what you are implying Captain). This third world country is growing fast with strong increases across most markets. However, two factors should be considered. First the huge disparity in wealth distribution. The average salary is still $2,670. That's per year. If it was per day it is only a decent day rate. Per month the UKs benefits scroungers would blanche. Although a new lower middle class (the sort CNSL need) is growing it doesn't seem consistent based on the figures I'm seeing. From a healthcare perspective basics like clean drinking water is beyond the majority. Basic food hygiene is a significant issue across the whole country. For most people in the country finding out food intolerances using a test with questionable scientific credibility may seem a bit far fetched. A growing market and an opportunity? Yes. Enough to save CNSL from the issues in other markets? Nope. I don't think so. This is before we get into the challenges of running a sales team, something that it would seem CNSL are struggling with (as predicted by your friendly genius). We are just over 3 months away from  the end of year for CNSL. A trading update should arrive around May but I am going to call this now. 1) They are going to turn over less than £8 million. - lowest since 2022/3 FY is looking likely. 2) They are going to hold less than £3 million in cash. On the plus side (because the idiots rarely get to the end) the changes to ISAs in 2027 may help them but that is a LONG way away. LOL.

data.thread_title: RE: Most Innovative Nutrition and Gut Health Company 2025 Award

data.author: CaptainSwag
data.content: Criticisms and "Pay-to-Play" Concerns Revenue Model: The primary concern raised by some in the business community is that the core business model of GHP's parent company, AI Global Media, is based on selling enhanced promotional packages (e.g., physical awards, extensive magazine coverage, marketing tools) to winners. These packages can be expensive, leading some to characterize the process as a form of "pay-to-play" marketing, even if the basic award itself is free. Nomination Process: Nominations often come from the in-house research team or third parties, meaning a business may be "alerted" that they've won an award without actively seeking it or knowing they were nominated. Perceived Value: The value of the award is debated. Some winners express genuine pride in the recognition, viewing it as a testament to their hard work and a boost to credibility and employee morale. Others consider the unsolicited awards to be "bogus" or a "scam" if the recipient hasn't even started their business yet, suggesting the vetting process is not rigorous enough. In summary, GHP awards are not an outright scam, as an assessment process does exist and the basic recognition is free. However, businesses should be aware that the primary goal of the program appears to be selling optional, high-cost promotional opportunities, and the perceived prestige may vary within the industry.
data.thread_title: RE: Most Innovative Nutrition and Gut Health Company 2025 Award

data.author: CaptainSwag
data.content: The International Elite 100 (IE 100) Awards appear to be a legitimate, though perhaps not highly prestigious, modern "cottage industry" awards program. They are not a scam in the sense of being "pay-to-win," as the initial award is free, but they primarily function by offering paid marketing and physical award packages to winners.

data.author: Atanasoff
data.content: Today's economic figures aren't good for CNSL. The UK market is key for CNSL despite it being near saturation. Discretionary spending is clearly taking a hit. The crystal gazing market has some robustness against this (a fool and its money) but my suspicion is that they will be like many other SME and seeing a fall in sales in the UK market. So how about its international ambitions? The US dollar has and continues to weaken against sterling. Trading is still tough for importers with tariffs and the general political mood music. I think sales are static at best. India was also another target (assuming that is what you are implying Captain). This third world country is growing fast with strong increases across most markets. However, two factors should be considered. First the huge disparity in wealth distribution. The average salary is still $2,670. That's per year. If it was per day it is only a decent day rate. Per month the UKs benefits scroungers would blanche. Although a new lower middle class (the sort CNSL need) is growing it doesn't seem consistent based on the figures I'm seeing. From a healthcare perspective basics like clean drinking water is beyond the majority. Basic food hygiene is a significant issue across the whole country. For most people in the country finding out food intolerances using a test with questionable scientific credibility may seem a bit far fetched. A growing market and an opportunity? Yes. Enough to save CNSL from the issues in other markets? Nope. I don't think so. This is before we get into the challenges of running a sales team, something that it would seem CNSL are struggling with (as predicted by your friendly genius). We are just over 3 months away from  the end of year for CNSL. A trading update should arrive around May but I am going to call this now. 1) They are going to turn over less than £8 million. - lowest since 2022/3 FY is looking likely. 2) They are going to hold less than £3 million in cash. On the plus side (because the idiots rarely get to the end) the changes to ISAs in 2027 may help them but that is a LONG way away. LOL.

data.author: CaptainSwag
data.content: Criticisms and "Pay-to-Play" Concerns Revenue Model: The primary concern raised by some in the business community is that the core business model of GHP's parent company, AI Global Media, is based on selling enhanced promotional packages (e.g., physical awards, extensive magazine coverage, marketing tools) to winners. These packages can be expensive, leading some to characterize the process as a form of "pay-to-play" marketing, even if the basic award itself is free. Nomination Process: Nominations often come from the in-house research team or third parties, meaning a business may be "alerted" that they've won an award without actively seeking it or knowing they were nominated. Perceived Value: The value of the award is debated. Some winners express genuine pride in the recognition, viewing it as a testament to their hard work and a boost to credibility and employee morale. Others consider the unsolicited awards to be "bogus" or a "scam" if the recipient hasn't even started their business yet, suggesting the vetting process is not rigorous enough. In summary, GHP awards are not an outright scam, as an assessment process does exist and the basic recognition is free. However, businesses should be aware that the primary goal of the program appears to be selling optional, high-cost promotional opportunities, and the perceived prestige may vary within the industry.
data.thread_title: RE: Most Innovative Nutrition and Gut Health Company 2025 Award

data.author: CaptainSwag
data.content: The International Elite 100 (IE 100) Awards appear to be a legitimate, though perhaps not highly prestigious, modern "cottage industry" awards program. They are not a scam in the sense of being "pay-to-win," as the initial award is free, but they primarily function by offering paid marketing and physical award packages to winners.

data.author: Atanasoff
data.content: Today's economic figures aren't good for CNSL. The UK market is key for CNSL despite it being near saturation. Discretionary spending is clearly taking a hit. The crystal gazing market has some robustness against this (a fool and its money) but my suspicion is that they will be like many other SME and seeing a fall in sales in the UK market. So how about its international ambitions? The US dollar has and continues to weaken against sterling. Trading is still tough for importers with tariffs and the general political mood music. I think sales are static at best. India was also another target (assuming that is what you are implying Captain). This third world country is growing fast with strong increases across most markets. However, two factors should be considered. First the huge disparity in wealth distribution. The average salary is still $2,670. That's per year. If it was per day it is only a decent day rate. Per month the UKs benefits scroungers would blanche. Although a new lower middle class (the sort CNSL need) is growing it doesn't seem consistent based on the figures I'm seeing. From a healthcare perspective basics like clean drinking water is beyond the majority. Basic food hygiene is a significant issue across the whole country. For most people in the country finding out food intolerances using a test with questionable scientific credibility may seem a bit far fetched. A growing market and an opportunity? Yes. Enough to save CNSL from the issues in other markets? Nope. I don't think so. This is before we get into the challenges of running a sales team, something that it would seem CNSL are struggling with (as predicted by your friendly genius). We are just over 3 months away from  the end of year for CNSL. A trading update should arrive around May but I am going to call this now. 1) They are going to turn over less than £8 million. - lowest since 2022/3 FY is looking likely. 2) They are going to hold less than £3 million in cash. On the plus side (because the idiots rarely get to the end) the changes to ISAs in 2027 may help them but that is a LONG way away. LOL.

data.author: Atanasoff
data.content: Today's economic figures aren't good for CNSL. The UK market is key for CNSL despite it being near saturation. Discretionary spending is clearly taking a hit. The crystal gazing market has some robustness against this (a fool and its money) but my suspicion is that they will be like many other SME and seeing a fall in sales in the UK market. So how about its international ambitions? The US dollar has and continues to weaken against sterling. Trading is still tough for importers with tariffs and the general political mood music. I think sales are static at best. India was also another target (assuming that is what you are implying Captain). This third world country is growing fast with strong increases across most markets. However, two factors should be considered. First the huge disparity in wealth distribution. The average salary is still $2,670. That's per year. If it was per day it is only a decent day rate. Per month the UKs benefits scroungers would blanche. Although a new lower middle class (the sort CNSL need) is growing it doesn't seem consistent based on the figures I'm seeing. From a healthcare perspective basics like clean drinking water is beyond the majority. Basic food hygiene is a significant issue across the whole country. For most people in the country finding out food intolerances using a test with questionable scientific credibility may seem a bit far fetched. A growing market and an opportunity? Yes. Enough to save CNSL from the issues in other markets? Nope. I don't think so. This is before we get into the challenges of running a sales team, something that it would seem CNSL are struggling with (as predicted by your friendly genius). We are just over 3 months away from  the end of year for CNSL. A trading update should arrive around May but I am going to call this now. 1) They are going to turn over less than £8 million. - lowest since 2022/3 FY is looking likely. 2) They are going to hold less than £3 million in cash. On the plus side (because the idiots rarely get to the end) the changes to ISAs in 2027 may help them but that is a LONG way away. LOL.

data.author: Atanasoff
data.content: Today's economic figures aren't good for CNSL. The UK market is key for CNSL despite it being near saturation. Discretionary spending is clearly taking a hit. The crystal gazing market has some robustness against this (a fool and its money) but my suspicion is that they will be like many other SME and seeing a fall in sales in the UK market. So how about its international ambitions? The US dollar has and continues to weaken against sterling. Trading is still tough for importers with tariffs and the general political mood music. I think sales are static at best. India was also another target (assuming that is what you are implying Captain). This third world country is growing fast with strong increases across most markets. However, two factors should be considered. First the huge disparity in wealth distribution. The average salary is still $2,670. That's per year. If it was per day it is only a decent day rate. Per month the UKs benefits scroungers would blanche. Although a new lower middle class (the sort CNSL need) is growing it doesn't seem consistent based on the figures I'm seeing. From a healthcare perspective basics like clean drinking water is beyond the majority. Basic food hygiene is a significant issue across the whole country. For most people in the country finding out food intolerances using a test with questionable scientific credibility may seem a bit far fetched. A growing market and an opportunity? Yes. Enough to save CNSL from the issues in other markets? Nope. I don't think so. This is before we get into the challenges of running a sales team, something that it would seem CNSL are struggling with (as predicted by your friendly genius). We are just over 3 months away from  the end of year for CNSL. A trading update should arrive around May but I am going to call this now. 1) They are going to turn over less than £8 million. - lowest since 2022/3 FY is looking likely. 2) They are going to hold less than £3 million in cash. On the plus side (because the idiots rarely get to the end) the changes to ISAs in 2027 may help them but that is a LONG way away. LOL.

data.author: Atanasoff
data.content: Today's economic figures aren't good for CNSL. The UK market is key for CNSL despite it being near saturation. Discretionary spending is clearly taking a hit. The crystal gazing market has some robustness against this (a fool and its money) but my suspicion is that they will be like many other SME and seeing a fall in sales in the UK market. So how about its international ambitions? The US dollar has and continues to weaken against sterling. Trading is still tough for importers with tariffs and the general political mood music. I think sales are static at best. India was also another target (assuming that is what you are implying Captain). This third world country is growing fast with strong increases across most markets. However, two factors should be considered. First the huge disparity in wealth distribution. The average salary is still $2,670. That's per year. If it was per day it is only a decent day rate. Per month the UKs benefits scroungers would blanche. Although a new lower middle class (the sort CNSL need) is growing it doesn't seem consistent based on the figures I'm seeing. From a healthcare perspective basics like clean drinking water is beyond the majority. Basic food hygiene is a significant issue across the whole country. For most people in the country finding out food intolerances using a test with questionable scientific credibility may seem a bit far fetched. A growing market and an opportunity? Yes. Enough to save CNSL from the issues in other markets? Nope. I don't think so. This is before we get into the challenges of running a sales team, something that it would seem CNSL are struggling with (as predicted by your friendly genius). We are just over 3 months away from  the end of year for CNSL. A trading update should arrive around May but I am going to call this now. 1) They are going to turn over less than £8 million. - lowest since 2022/3 FY is looking likely. 2) They are going to hold less than £3 million in cash. On the plus side (because the idiots rarely get to the end) the changes to ISAs in 2027 may help them but that is a LONG way away. LOL.

data.content: Now read it in the time it took the share price to hit 2.25p This is now a record low (remember my post about the potential for it to hit this?) A sales team not performing after 6 months won't perform unless changed. Sales people are different from account managers. data.author: Atanasoff
data.content: Today's economic figures aren't good for CNSL. The UK market is key for CNSL despite it being near saturation. Discretionary spending is clearly taking a hit. The crystal gazing market has some robustness against this (a fool and its money) but my suspicion is that they will be like many other SME and seeing a fall in sales in the UK market. So how about its international ambitions? The US dollar has and continues to weaken against sterling. Trading is still tough for importers with tariffs and the general political mood music. I think sales are static at best. India was also another target (assuming that is what you are implying Captain). This third world country is growing fast with strong increases across most markets. However, two factors should be considered. First the huge disparity in wealth distribution. The average salary is still $2,670. That's per year. If it was per day it is only a decent day rate. Per month the UKs benefits scroungers would blanche. Although a new lower middle class (the sort CNSL need) is growing it doesn't seem consistent based on the figures I'm seeing. From a healthcare perspective basics like clean drinking water is beyond the majority. Basic food hygiene is a significant issue across the whole country. For most people in the country finding out food intolerances using a test with questionable scientific credibility may seem a bit far fetched. A growing market and an opportunity? Yes. Enough to save CNSL from the issues in other markets? Nope. I don't think so. This is before we get into the challenges of running a sales team, something that it would seem CNSL are struggling with (as predicted by your friendly genius). We are just over 3 months away from  the end of year for CNSL. A trading update should arrive around May but I am going to call this now. 1) They are going to turn over less than £8 million. - lowest since 2022/3 FY is looking likely. 2) They are going to hold less than £3 million in cash. On the plus side (because the idiots rarely get to the end) the changes to ISAs in 2027 may help them but that is a LONG way away. LOL.

data.author: Atanasoff
data.content: Today's economic figures aren't good for CNSL. The UK market is key for CNSL despite it being near saturation. Discretionary spending is clearly taking a hit. The crystal gazing market has some robustness against this (a fool and its money) but my suspicion is that they will be like many other SME and seeing a fall in sales in the UK market. So how about its international ambitions? The US dollar has and continues to weaken against sterling. Trading is still tough for importers with tariffs and the general political mood music. I think sales are static at best. India was also another target (assuming that is what you are implying Captain). This third world country is growing fast with strong increases across most markets. However, two factors should be considered. First the huge disparity in wealth distribution. The average salary is still $2,670. That's per year. If it was per day it is only a decent day rate. Per month the UKs benefits scroungers would blanche. Although a new lower middle class (the sort CNSL need) is growing it doesn't seem consistent based on the figures I'm seeing. From a healthcare perspective basics like clean drinking water is beyond the majority. Basic food hygiene is a significant issue across the whole country. For most people in the country finding out food intolerances using a test with questionable scientific credibility may seem a bit far fetched. A growing market and an opportunity? Yes. Enough to save CNSL from the issues in other markets? Nope. I don't think so. This is before we get into the challenges of running a sales team, something that it would seem CNSL are struggling with (as predicted by your friendly genius). We are just over 3 months away from  the end of year for CNSL. A trading update should arrive around May but I am going to call this now. 1) They are going to turn over less than £8 million. - lowest since 2022/3 FY is looking likely. 2) They are going to hold less than £3 million in cash. On the plus side (because the idiots rarely get to the end) the changes to ISAs in 2027 may help them but that is a LONG way away. LOL.

data.content: Wow - H50 is in the house ! LOL. Things must be bad. Let's break this down: "For most of this afternoon the stock was 'at best' only on any size, another nutritional company yesterday informed the market their results would beat expectations by some margin," Is this like one of the CAPTCHA tests where we select a sentence from a random words? You word salad makes no sense. But it is amusing because.... "this has to be a positive for CNSL being in the same sector." what a leap you've made. LOOK A COMPANY IN ROUGHLY THE SAME SECTOR IS DOING WELL. Now, let me try and make this simple enough for you to understand. H50 is running a kids disco for some chav kids birthday party. The birthday cake has 10 slices. Each child is given a slice but then "billy big balls" takes Brooklyn, Luke, Shane and Tylers slice from them. Question - Because Billy is doing well on the cake consumption part does that mean Luke, Shane and Tyler are also doing well? LOL. What a total loser you must be. My guess is you're a "cash in hand" sort. "After the late tick up there were only £5k of shares were available online, after that they wanted a premium."
